terms.definition: Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted by a service provider and accessed via the internet
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to see revision history and revert to previous versions
A unified system where all documents are stored in one secure, accessible location rather than scattered across multiple systems or folders
A security method that restricts system access to authorized users based on their specific roles and responsibilities within an organization
A chronological record of all activities and changes made to documents or systems, providing accountability and traceability
The ability for multiple users to work on and edit documents simultaneously, with changes visible instantly to all participants
The process of monitoring and recording all interactions, changes, and movements of documents throughout their lifecycle
Transportation Management System - software that helps plan, execute, and optimize the movement of goods in supply chains
Warehouse Management System - software that controls and manages warehouse operations including inventory tracking and order fulfillment
The systematic approach to ensuring that documentation and processes meet regulatory requirements and industry standards
Pre-formatted document structures that provide a standardized format and ensure consistency across similar types of documentation
The process of converting data into a coded format to prevent unauthorized access and ensure document security
The exchange of information and documentation between all parties involved in a project or process, including suppliers, partners, and customers
The process of making changes or updates to existing documents, typically tracked through version control systems
